content.description: SDS or you probably won't get it. Heavily chalked up right side pull and left sloper. Make your way up left toward the pockets and cracks. Slim and curved feet. Hang your body left away from the slim side pull and make use of the left arete until you can top out over the corner.Grasping those cracks, pockets and side pulls is the crux. Once you get that, you're gold.Put it at a 2+, but open to additional opinions for a firm rating. It's easier than the V3 but only a little.Two spotters recommended because you could fall sideways in either direction with serious risk of hitting your head on the rock right behind you (regular pad wouldn't even fit long ways, had to fold it in half against that rock)
content.protection: Pad, protect against the rock behind you
content.location: Furthest left position of the rock, further than all the photos here. Makes use of the left arete. Start between the boulder and the rock right behind you.

content.description: Looking for more of a challenge? then give this crimptastic route a try :)
content.location: Start at "Definitely Not Butterscotch" and go up and to the left instead. Follow the chalky crimps to the top.

content.description: The hardest route viable on the butterscotch slab. The original finder of this boulder is seen climbing this route in the photo. Be prepared to be defeated :P Features crimps on a much more vertical section of the slab, good footwork is rewarded.
content.location: About as far left as you can go on the butterscotch slab, look for tiny chalked up crimps.

climbs.name: I can't believe it's not butterscotch

content.description: A nice place to start on this slab, this route is full of large ledges and cracks.
content.location: On the far right side of the climbing face, near the Jeffery Pine tree that's rubbing right up against the boulder.

content.description: A route on the butterscotch slab that offers a little more of a challenge. Features crimps, cracks, and the final ledge ending of "I can't believe it's not butterscotch".
content.location: found more towards the middle of the climbing face. about 4 feet left of the V0 route found next door.

content.description: A west facing slab about 12 feet high. Routes range from V0 - V4. It's a nice spot to warm up for the main wall of Trippy Rock. Due to the abundance of Jeffery Pines in the area, you may smell butterscotch on warm days here.
